Euclidean Zoning.definition: a system of zoning whereby a town or community is divided into areas in which specific uses of land are permitted
Euclidean Zoning.origin: [from Village of Euclid, Ohio et al. v. Ambler Realty Co. , 272 U.S. 365 (1926), case in which the Supreme Court upheld the right of a locality to enforce such a system]

1.1: a system of zoning whereby a town or community is divided into areas in which specific uses of land are permitted
